required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Breast for Success: A Family-Centered Intervention in Support of Breastfeeding Among High-risk Low-income Mothers
clinical_study.official_title: Breast for Success: A Family-Centered Intervention in Support of Breastfeeding Among High-risk Low-income Mothers in Cleveland

brief_summary.textblock:
Breast for Success is a new direct service program focused on overcoming barriers to breastfeeding for low-income inner-city mothers by use of a culturally competent and home-based educational and support intervention. Key project components include a new Enhanced Breastfeeding Curriculum with brief engaging health literacy focused modules, and two innovative support plans, the Breastfeeding Doula and Father Support Programs. The objective is to increase breastfeeding rates for high-risk inner-city mothers.
Research Questions to evaluate project feasibility and effectiveness are:
1. Were all aspects of the Curriculum and Doula and Father Support Programs implemented?
2. Is there an increase in the rate of any breastfeeding at 1 month postpartum for all mothers?
3. Is there a difference in the rate of any breastfeeding at 1 month postpartum between interventions (Curriculum only, Curriculum+Doula Support, Curriculum+Father Support)?
4. What are exclusive breastfeeding rates at 1, 3 and 6 months for all mothers?

detailed_description.textblock: Low rates of breastfeeding among low-income inner-city mothers represent a challenging health disparity that adversely impacts child and maternal health. The overall objective of Breast for Success is to increase the rates of breastfeeding initiation, continuation and exclusivity among high-risk mothers in the City of Cleveland via home-based culturally appropriate interventions. Key project components include a new Curriculum with brief engaging modules utilizing games, teach-reteach strategies, and interactive learning to address specific barriers identified in focus groups (e.g. pain, low milk supply, breast "myths"), and two innovative support components, the Breastfeeding Doula and Father Support Programs. Breast for Success was developed in collaboration with and will be disseminated in partnership with the Cleveland Department of Public Health MomsFirst initiative (a Healthy Start Program), which delivers comprehensive services including twice-monthly Community Health Worker home visits prenatally through 2 years postpartum to 500 women annually. The investigators will measure program success via participation logs, satisfaction questionnaires and breastfeeding rates at 1, 3 and 6 months postpartum.

primary_outcome.description: Measure program feasibility by number of participants who were exposed to the intervention for whom there is any feeding outcome
Measure program feasibility by counting the number of Breastfeeding Curricular modules that were presented of total possible = 11

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Any breastfeeding: participants were followed for the duration of hospital stay, an average of 48 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Measure rate of any breastfeeding (breastfeeding initiation) in the hospital. We will also compare this rate between the 3 intervention groups.

secondary_outcome.measure: Breastfeeding Rate at One Month Postpartum
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Any and exclusive breastfeeding at one month, between 21-38 days postpartum
secondary_outcome.description: Measure rate of breastfeeding (rate of any breastfeeding is main measure, also measure rate of exclusive breastfeeding) at one month postpartum. Will compare rate of any breastfeeding one month postpartum to historical data, and will compare rates of any breastfeeding at one month postpartum between intervention groups.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Any and exclusive breastfeeding at 3 months, between 10-14 weeks postpartum
secondary_outcome.description: Measure rates of any and exclusive breastfeeding at 3 months postpartum. Rate of any breastfeeding is presented.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Any and exclusive breastfeeding at 6 months, between 22-26 weeks postpartum
secondary_outcome.description: Measure breastfeeding rate (any and exclusive) at 6 months postpartum. Rate of any breastfeeding is presented.

arm_group.description: New Enhanced Breastfeeding Curriculum with 11 brief modules
Enhanced Curriculum + mother selects a support person to learn about breastfeeding with her and support her postpartum ("breastfeeding doula")
Enhanced Curriculum+ mother provides father-friendly information about breastfeeding to her partner plus an invitation to an educational group for fathers

intervention.description: Brief health literacy focused modules on breastfeeding delivered in the home by Community Health Workers

In the Doula Program, the Community Health Worker and mother will identify a support person (e.g. grandma, father, friend) who commits to learning about breastfeeding with the mother at home visits, and then helps her with breastfeeding postpartum.

In the Father Support Program, mothers will give their partners father-friendly breastfeeding information and an invitation to a 3-week breastfeeding education group for fathers that includes a resource specialist or resource information for child support, re-entry and job services.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- pregnant woman enrolled in MomsFirst Program of Greater Cleveland
Exclusion Criteria:
- incarceration
Other study populations include the Community Health Workers, the doulas and the fathers of the study mothers.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Program Feasibility- Feeding Outcome Collected
outcome.description: Measure program feasibility by number of participants who were exposed to the intervention for whom there is any feeding outcome
outcome.population: Total number of eligible MomsFirst participants who agreed to data sharing. Outcome shows number w/ any feeding outcome (not lost to follow up, no live birth, case closed by MomsFirst). This is for a 24 month period since all data was de-identified and stripped of dates so unable to specify for 12 month period

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: UHospitalsCleveland; Rainbow Babies and CHildren's Hospital
